questions.text: Which of the following is not an outdoor air pollutants?
questions.solution:
• Outdoor air pollutants: sulfur dioxide, CO, ozone, nitrogen dioxide, lead, and particulate matter.
  • OZONE (O3) :- produced by interaction of ultraviolet (UV) radiation and oxygen (O2 ) in the stratosphere and naturally accumulates in the so-called ozone layer 10 to 30 miles above the earth's surface. This layer protects life on earth by absorbing the most dangerous UV radiation emitted by the sun.
    • Ozone That accumulates in the lower atmosphere (ground-level ozone) is one of the most pernicious air pollutants.
  • PARTICULATES :- Fine or ultrafine particles less than 10 µm in diameter are the most harmful.
  • CARBON MONOXIDE :- CO is a systemic asphyxiant that is an important cause of accidental and suicidal death.

Key Takeaways:

  • Familiarize yourself with the six common outdoor air pollutants: sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, ozone, nitrogen dioxide, lead, and particulate matter.
  • Understand that ozone at the ground level (not in the stratosphere) is harmful.
  • Fine particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10) poses severe risks to human health, especially for vulnerable populations.

questions.text: The role of cytochrome P-450 system in xenobiotics is?
questions.solution:
XENOBIOTICS are exogenous chemicals in the environment in air, water, food, and soil that may be absorbed into the body through inhalation, ingestion, and skin contact.

  • The reactions that metabolize xenobiotics into nontoxic products or that activate xenobiotics to generate toxic compounds (Figs. 9.2 and 9.3) occur in two phases
  • The most important catalyst of phase I reactions is the cytochrome P-450 enzyme system.
  • Cytochrome P-450 enzymes (CYPs) à Heme-containing enzymes
    • Primarily expressed in hepatocytes, skin, lungs, gastrointestinal mucosa, and other organs.
    • catalyzes reactions that either detoxify xenobiotics (choice B) or, less commonly, convert xenobiotics into active compounds that cause cellular injury (choice A).
    • Both types of reactions produce à Reactive oxygen species (ROS), which can cause cellular damage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cytochrome P-450 enzymes catalyze Phase I metabolic reactions, which may lead to detoxification or activation of xenobiotics.
  • The dual role of CYP enzymes makes A & B correct.
  • ROS generation during metabolism can cause collateral damage, highlighting the importance of balanced cellular repair mechanisms.

choices.text: Punctate basophilic stippling of red cells
Ring sideroblasts in prussian blue stain in bone marrow
CNS is less commonly affected in adults
Reduced red cell free protoporphyrin levels

questions.solution:
• LEAD (high affinity for sulfhydryl groups) à interferes with two enzymes involved in heme synthesis: delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase and
  • Iron incorporation into heme is impaired à leading to microcytosis (small red cells) and anemia.
  • Lead inhibits sodium- and potassium-dependent adenosine triphosphatases (ATPases) in cell membranes, an effect that may increase the fragility of red cells, causing hemolysis.
  • neurologic changes in children or unexplained microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling in red cells in adults and children.
  • Elevated blood lead and red cell free protoporphyrin levels (greater than 50 µg/dL) (choice D) or, alternatively, zinc protoporphyrin levels, are required for definitive diagnosis.
  • Bone marrow changes :- The inhibition of ferrochelatase by lead à appearance of a few ring sideroblasts, (choice B) red cell precursors with iron-laden mitochondria that are detected with a Prussian blue stain.
  • In the peripheral blood à microcytic, hypochromic anemia, punctate basophilic stippling of the red cells. (Choice A)
  • Brain damage is prone to occur in children. In young children, sensory, motor, intellectual, and psychologic changes
    • In adults the CNS is less often affected, (choice but frequently a peripheral demyelinating neuropathy appears, typically involving the motor nerves of the most commonly used muscles. Thus the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers are often the first to be affected (causing wristdrop), followed by paralysis of the peroneal muscles (causing footdrop)

Key Takeaways:

  • Lead poisoning causes elevated, not reduced, red cell free protoporphyrin levels.
  • Look for hallmark findings: basophilic stippling, ring sideroblasts, microcytic anemia, and neurologic symptoms depending on age.
  • CNS damage is more common in children, while adults experience peripheral neuropathy.

choices.text: Main source of exposure is contaminated fish
High levels of this metal makes a exposure of the fetus in utero

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement about Minamata disease from the following:
questions.solution:
Minamata disease is a CNS disorder caused by eating fish and shellfish contaminated with methylmercury, a toxic form of mercury. (Choice A)

  • Three forms of mercury:
    1. Metallic mercury (also referred to as elemental mercury)
    2. Inorganic mercury compounds (mostly mercuric chloride)
    3. Organic mercury (mostly methyl mercury)
  • The main sources of exposure to mercury are CONTAMINATED FISH (choice C) (methyl mercury) and mercury vapours released from metallic mercury in dental amalgams, a possible occupational hazard for dental workers.
  • Inorganic mercury from the natural degassing of the Earth's crust or from industrial contamination is converted to organic compounds such as methyl mercury by bacteria.
  • Methyl mercury enters the food chain, and in carnivorous fish such as swordfish, shark, and bluefish, mercury levels may be 1 million times higher than in the surrounding water.
    • Almost 90% of ingested methyl mercury is absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract.
    • The consumption of fish contaminated by the release of methyl mercury from industrial sources in Minamata Bay and the Agano River in Japan caused widespread mortality and morbidity.
    • The medical disorders associated with the Minamata episode became known as MINAMATA DISEASE and include cerebral palsy, deafness, blindness, intellectual disability, and major CNS defects in children exposed in utero (choice B & D)
    • Acute exposure through consumption of bread made from grain treated with a methyl mercury-based fungicide in Iraq in 1971 resulted in hundreds of deaths and thousands of hospitalizations.

Key Takeaways:

  • Minamata disease results from methylmercury poisoning, primarily due to contaminated fish consumption.
  • It affects the CNS, causing severe neurological and developmental defects, particularly in fetuses exposed in utero.
  • The source of contamination in historical cases was industrial pollution, emphasizing the importance of environmental monitoring.

questions.text: Ouch-ouch disease is caused by which of the following metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
• CADMIUM is preferentially toxic to the kidneys and the lungs through uncertain mechanisms that may involve increased production of ROS.
  • It is an occupational and environmental pollutant generated by mining, electroplating, and production of nickel-cadmium batteries, which are usually disposed of as household waste.
  • Cadmium can contaminate the soil and plants directly or through fertilizers and irrigation water.
  • The most important source of cadmium exposure :- Food
  • Its toxic effects require its uptake into cells via transporters such as ZIP8, which normally serves as a transporter for zinc.
  • The principal toxic effects of excess cadmium are a form of obstructive lung disease caused by necrosis of alveolar epithelial cells and renal tubular damage that may progress to end-stage renal disease.
  • Cadmium exposure can also cause skeletal abnormalities associated with calcium loss.
  • Cadmium-containing water used to irrigate rice fields in Japan caused a disease in postmenopausal women known as itai-itai ("ouch-ouch"), a combination of osteoporosis and osteomalacia associated with renal disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cadmium poisoning is the cause of Itai-Itai disease.
  • It primarily affects the kidneys, bones, and lungs, with symptoms of renal disease, bone pain, and fractures.
  • Preventing exposure to cadmium in food and water is critical for public health.

questions.text: The principal toxic effect of excess of cadmium is?
questions.solution:
• CADMIUM is preferentially toxic to the kidneys and the lungs through uncertain mechanisms that may involve increased production of ROS.
  • It is an occupational and environmental pollutant generated by mining, electroplating, and production of nickel-cadmium batteries, which are usually disposed of as household waste.
  • Cadmium can contaminate the soil and plants directly or through fertilizers and irrigation water.
  • The most important source of cadmium exposure :- Food
  • Its toxic effects require its uptake into cells via transporters such as ZIP8, which normally serves as a transporter for zinc.
  • The principal toxic effects of excess cadmium are a form of obstructive lung disease (choice B) caused by necrosis of alveolar epithelial cells and renal tubular damage that may progress to end-stage renal disease.
  • Cadmium exposure can also cause skeletal abnormalities associated with calcium loss.
  • Cadmium-containing water used to irrigate rice fields in Japan caused a disease in postmenopausal women known as itai-itai ("ouch-ouch"), a combination of osteoporosis and osteomalacia associated with renal disease.
  • Cadmium toxicity doesn't affect bladder & colon. Cerebral palsy has not been reported in cadmium toxicity cases yet.

Key Difficulty:

  • Obstructive lung disease is a principal toxic effect of cadmium due to necrosis of alveolar cells.
  • Cadmium also causes renal damage and skeletal abnormalities.
  • Prevention of cadmium exposure through better industrial practices and environmental safeguards is essential.

questions.text: How much concentration of alcohol in blood is the legal definition of drunk driving?
questions.solution:
• After consumption, ethanol is absorbed unaltered in the stomach and small intestine and then distributes throughout the body in direct proportion to the blood level.
  • Less than 10% is excreted unchanged in the urine, sweat, and breath.
  • The amount exhaled is proportional to the blood level and forms the basis for the breath test used by law enforcement agencies.
  • A concentration of 80 mg/dL in the blood constitutes the legal definition of drunk driving.
  • For an average individual, this alcohol concentration is reached after consumption of three standard drinks, about three (12 ounce) bottles of beer, 15 oz of wine, or 4 to 5 oz of 80-proof distilled spirits.
    • Drowsiness occurs at 200 mg/ dL
    • Stupor at 300 mg/dL
    • Coma, with possible respiratory arrest, at higher levels.
  • The rate of metabolism affects the blood alcohol level.

Key Takeaways:

  • Legal Limit for Drunk Driving: A blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 80 mg/dL (0.08%) defines drunk driving, typically reached after 3 standard drinks.
  • Alcohol Effects by BAC: Drowsiness occurs at 200 mg/dL, stupor at 300 mg/dL, and coma or respiratory arrest at levels above 400 mg/dL.

choices.text: Reduces the risk of breast cancer
Decreases the risk of stroke & pulmonary embolism

questions.solution:
• Combination estrogen-progestin increases the risk of breast cancer after a median time of 5 to 6 years. By contrast,
    • Estrogen alone in women with hysterectomy is associated with a borderline reduction in risk of breast cancer. (choice A) there is no increase in the risk for ovarian cancer.
  • MHT may have a protective effect on the development of atherosclerosis (choice B) and coronary disease in women younger than age 60 years, but there is no protection in women who started MHT at an older age.
    • Protective effects in younger women depend in part on the response of estrogen receptors in healthy vascular endothelium.
    • MHT should not be used for prevention of cardiovascular disease or other chronic diseases.
  • MHT increases the risk of stroke and VTE including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. ('choice C)
    • The increase in VTE is more pronounced during the first 2 years of treatment and in women who have other risk factors, such as immobilization and hypercoagulable states caused by prothrombin or factor V Leiden mutation
  • MHT use in postmenopausal women could prevent or slow the progression of osteoporosis (Choice D) and reduce the likelihood of myocardial infarction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Breast Cancer Risk: Estrogen-progestin therapy increases breast cancer risk after 5-6 years, while estrogen alone (for women with hysterectomy) may slightly reduce the risk.
  • Benefits and Risks of MHT: Menopausal hormonal therapy (MHT) may slow osteoporosis progression but increases the risk of stroke, venous thromboembolism (VTE), and pulmonary embolism, particularly in the first two years of treatment.

questions.text: Overdose of acetaminophen is treated by administration of:
questions.solution:
• The window between the usual dose (0.5 g) and the toxic dose (15 to 25 g) is large, and acetaminophen is ordinarily very safe.
  • Toxicity begins with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and sometimes shock, followed in a few days by evidence of jaundice.
  • Overdose of acetaminophen can be treated in its early stages (within 12 hours) by administration of N-acetylcysteine, which restores GSH levels.
  • In serious overdose, liver failure ensues, starting with centrilobular necrosis that may extend to entire lobules; in such circumstances liver transplantation is the only hope for survival.

Key Takeaways:

  • Treatment: Acetaminophen overdose is treated with N-acetylcysteine, which replenishes glutathione (GSH) levels, preventing severe liver damage if administered within 12 hours of overdose.
  • Toxicity Symptoms: Overdose symptoms include nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and shock, potentially progressing to jaundice and liver failure. Severe cases may require liver transplantation.

choices.text: Blocks the reuptake of dopamine in the CNS
Blocks the reuptake of epinephrine and norepinephrine at adrenergic nerve endings
Stimulates the presynaptic release of norepinephrine

questions.text: All are true about cocaine EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Cocaine facilitates neurotransmission :-
    • In the CNS à Blocks the reuptake of dopamine (choice A)
    • At adrenergic nerve endings à Blocks the reuptake of both epinephrine and norepinephrine (choice B)
    • Stimulating the presynaptic release of norepinephrine (choice C)
  • The euphoria is due to its enhancement of brain dopamine activity, especially in the so-called mesolimbic dopamine reward pathway.
  • Cocaine produces intense euphoria and neurologic stimulation, making it one of the most addictive drugs.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mechanism of Action: Cocaine enhances neurotransmission by blocking dopamine reuptake in the CNS, and epinephrine and norepinephrine reuptake at adrenergic nerve endings. It also stimulates the presynaptic release of norepinephrine.
  • Addictive Potential: Cocaine's intense euphoria and stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine reward pathway make it highly addictive.

choices.text: A - III, B - I, C - II
A- I, B - II, C - III
A - III, B - II, C - I
A - II, B - III, C - I

questions.text: Match the following drug abusers and the plant it's been derived from:
questions.solution:
• COCAINE is extracted from the leaves of the coca plant and is usually prepared as a water-soluble powder, cocaine hydrochloride. Cocaine sold on the street is liberally diluted with talcum powder, lactose, or other look-alikes. It can be snorted or dissolved in water and injected subcutaneously or intravenously
  • HEROIN is a street drug derived from the poppy plant that Is closely related to morphine. Use of heroin is even more harmful than cocaine use. As sold on the street, it is cut (diluted) with an agent (often talc or quinine); thus the size of the dose is not only variable but also usually unknown to the buyer. Heroin, along with any contaminating substances, is usually self-administered intravenously or subcutaneously.
  • MARIJUANA is made from the leaves of the Cannabis sativa plant, which contain the psychoactive substance Δ9 tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). About 5% to 10% of THC is absorbed when it is smoked in a hand-rolled cigarette ("joint").

choices.text: Decrease calcium levels in skeletal muscle leading to muscle rigidity

questions.solution:
• MALIGNANT HYPERTHERMIA :-
    • despite the name, is not caused by exposure to high temperatures (choice A)
    • genetic condition resulting from mutations in genes such as RYR1 (choice B) that control calcium levels in skeletal muscle cells.
    • In affected individuals, exposure to certain anaesthetics during surgery triggers a rapid rise in calcium levels in skeletal muscle, leading to muscle rigidity (choice C) and increased heat production.
    • The resulting hyperthermia has a mortality rate of approximately 80% if untreated, but this falls to less than 5% if the condition is recognized and muscle relaxants are administered promptly.

Key takeaways:

  • Cause and Trigger: Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition, often caused by RYR1 gene mutations, which leads to abnormal calcium regulation in skeletal muscle cells. It is triggered by exposure to certain anaesthetics, not high temperatures.
  • Clinical Features and Treatment: Affected individuals experience muscle rigidity and increased heat production due to elevated calcium levels in muscles. Prompt recognition and treatment with muscle relaxants (e.g., dantrolene) reduce mortality significantly.

choices.text: A - I - ii, B - II - iii, C - III - i
A - II - iii, B - I - i, C - III - ii
A - II - i, B - III - ii, C - I - iii
A - III - ii, B - I - iii, C - II - i

questions.text: Match the total body ionizing radiation injury to particular cell and/or organ, particular dosage in sievert (sv) & the time of develop to injury:
questions.solution:
1. Dose: 2-10 Sv (Bone Marrow)
    • Main site of injury: Bone marrow
    • Time to develop: 2-6 weeks
    • Reason: Radiation doses in this range cause hematopoietic syndrome. Bone marrow suppression leads to pancytopenia, resulting in increased risk of infections and bleeding.
  2. Dose: >50 Sv (Brain)
    • Main site of injury: Brain
    • Time to develop: 1-4 hours
    • Reason: At extremely high doses, neurological syndrome develops almost immediately, characterized by seizures, coma, and death due to brain edema.
  3. Dose: 1-2 Sv (Lymphocytes)
    • Main site of injury: Lymphocytes
    • Time to develop: 1 day to 1 week
    • Reason: Lymphocytes are highly radiosensitive and are depleted within hours to days, leading to immune system dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: Incorrect because brain injury occurs at doses >50 Sv, not at 2-10 Sv.
  • Option C: Incorrect because bone marrow suppression takes 2-6 weeks to manifest, not 1-4 hours.
  • Option D: Incorrect because lymphocyte depletion occurs within days, not at doses >50 Sv.

Key Takeaways:

  • Radiation Sensitivity: Different tissues and organs have varying sensitivities to ionizing radiation:
    • Lymphocytes (1-2 Sv): Affected rapidly due to their radiosensitivity.
    • Bone Marrow (2-10 Sv): Hematopoietic syndrome develops over weeks.
    • Brain (>50 Sv): High doses cause immediate neurological damage.
  • Dosage and Timing: The severity and timing of radiation injuries correlate with the dose:
    • Lower doses affect radiosensitive cells first (lymphocytes, bone marrow).
    • Higher doses (>50 Sv) cause rapid, fatal neurological damage.

questions.text: The bone marrow biopsy reveals increased fat and deposition of mucinous matrix material is pathognomic of which disease?
questions.solution:
ANOREXIA NERVOSA :-

  • Self-induced starvation à marked weight loss
  • The highest death rate of any psychiatric disorder
  • The clinical findings in anorexia nervosa are generally Similar to those in severe acute malnutrition (SAM) + effects on the endocrine system are prominent.
    • Amenorrhea, resulting from decreased secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone and (as a result) luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone,
    • Decreased thyroid hormone release à cold intolerance, bradycardia, constipation, and changes in the skin and hair.
    • Dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities.
    • Dry and scaly skin
    • Increased fat in the marrow (paradoxically, since fat is decreased elsewhere) associated with a peculiar deposition of mucinous matrix material that is referred to as gelatinous transformation is virtually pathognomonic for anorexia nervosa.
    • The bone density is decreased, most likely because of low estrogen levels, mimicking the postmenopausal acceleration of osteoporosis.
    • Anemia, lymphopenia, and hypoalbuminemia
  • A major complication of anorexia nervosa (and bulimia) is an increased susceptibility to cardiac arrhythmia and sudden death, resulting from hypokalemia

BULIMIA :-

  • The patient binges on food and then induces vomiting.
  • Bulimia is more common than anorexia nervosa and generally has a better prognosis
  • Occur in 1% to 2% of women and 0.1% of men, with an average onset at 20 years of age.
  • In bulimia, binge eating is the norm. Large amounts of Food, principally carbohydrates, are ingested, followed by induced vomiting. Although
  • Menstrual irregularities are common, amenorrhea occurs in less than 50% of bulimic patients because weight and gonadotropin levels remain near normal.
  • The major medical complications relate to frequent vomiting and the chronic use of laxatives and diuretics.
  • Electrolyte imbalances (hypokalemia), which predispose the patient to cardiac arrhythmias;
  • Pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents; and
  • Esophageal and gastric rupture.
  • These eating disorders occur primarily in previously healthy young women who have developed an obsession with body image and thinness.

Why other options are incorrect:-

a) Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):

  • SAM leads to generalized atrophy of tissues and organs, including bone marrow, but does not specifically show gelatinous transformation with increased fat and mucinous matrix in the bone marrow.

b) Osteoporosis:

  • Osteoporosis involves reduced bone mass and density, often due to hormonal imbalances (e.g., postmenopausal estrogen deficiency). However, it does not present with the gelatinous transformation of bone marrow seen in anorexia nervosa.

c) Ionizing Radiation:

  • Ionizing radiation can damage the bone marrow, leading to hypocellularity and fibrosis but does not result in increased fat or mucinous matrix deposition characteristic of anorexia nervosa.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bone Marrow Findings in Anorexia Nervosa:
    • Increased fat deposition and gelatinous transformation of the bone marrow are pathognomonic for anorexia nervosa.
  • Systemic Effects of Anorexia Nervosa:
    • Key clinical features include amenorrhea, low bone density, bradycardia, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death (often due to hypokalemia).
  • Distinction Between Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia:
    • Anorexia nervosa involves self-induced starvation with severe weight loss, while bulimia includes binge eating followed by purging, with more frequent electrolyte imbalances and esophageal complications.

choices.text: A - IV, B - III, C - II, D - V, E - I
A - VI, B - II, C - I, D - V, E - III
A - II, B - V, C - IV, D - III, E - I
A - III, B - I, C - II, D - V, E - IV

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution:
The symptoms of acute vitamin A toxicity include headache, dizziness, vomiting, stupor, and blurred vision, symptoms that may be confused with those of a brain tumor (pseudotumor cerebri).

  • The gross skeletal changes in rickets (Vitamin D deficiency) depend on the severity and duration of the process and, in particular, the stresses to which individual bones are subjected. During the nonambulatory stage of infancy, the head and chest sustain the greatest stresses. The softened occipital bones may become flattened, and the parietal bones can be buckled inward by pressure; with the release of the pressure, elastic recoil snaps the bones back into their original positions (craniotabes)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of leptin?
questions.solution:
3 important components of the afferent system, which regulates appetite and satiety:

  • Leptin
  • Gut hormones
  • Adiponectin, which regulates energy consumption.
  • LEPTIN:- Leptin is secreted by fat cells, and its output is regulated by the adequacy of fat stores.
    • Leptin regulates food intake (choice B) :- BMI and body fat stores are directly related to leptin secretion.
      • With abundant adipose tissue, leptin secretion is stimulated and it crosses the blood-brain barrier and travels to the hypothalamus, where it reduces food intake by stimulating POMC/CART neurons and inhibiting NPY/AgRP neurons.
      • The opposite sequence of events occurs when there are inadequate stores Of body fat: leptin secretion is diminished, and food intake is increased.
      • In persons of stable weight, the activities of these pathways are balanced.
    • Leptin regulates energy expenditure (choice D) :- An abundance of leptin stimulates physical activity, heat production, and energy expenditure.
      • The neurohumoral mediators of leptin-induced energy expenditure are less well defined.
  • Thermogenesis (choice B) :- an important catabolic effect mediated by leptin, is controlled in part by hypothalamic signals that increase the release of norepinephrine from sympathetic nerve endings in adipose tissue.
  • Adiponectin - Stimulates fatty acid oxidation in skeletal muscle, thereby REDUCING FATTY ACID LEVELS, not leptin (choice A)

Key Takeaways:

  • Functions of Leptin:
    • Regulates food intake: Leptin decreases appetite by acting on hypothalamic neurons (stimulating POMC/CART and inhibiting NPY/AgRP).
    • Maintains thermogenesis: Leptin promotes heat production through hypothalamic signals and increases norepinephrine release.
    • Regulates energy expenditure: Leptin enhances physical activity, heat production, and energy expenditure, particularly in the presence of abundant fat stores.
  • What Leptin Does NOT Do:
    • Reduces fatty acid levels: This is a function of adiponectin, which stimulates fatty acid oxidation in skeletal muscle, thereby lowering fatty acid levels, not leptin.

questions.text: Choose the correct component of the afferent system which has a role in obesity associated insulin resistance and type -2 diabetes from the following.
questions.solution:
ADIPONECTIN :-

  • produced in the adipose tissue, has been
  • Also been called a "fat-burning molecule," as it stimulates fatty acid oxidation in skeletal muscle, thereby REDUCING FATTY ACID LEVELS.
  • excess fatty acids can cross the blood-brain barrier à enter the hypothalamus (sensed by microglial cells) à These cells respond by releasing inflammatory factors (act on hypothalamic neurons) à to cause leptin resistance à blunting its antiadiposity signals.
  • Because of its actions on reducing fatty acids by promoting their oxidation, adiponectin is called the "guardian angel against obesity."
  • Adiponectin function :-
    • decreases glucose production in the liver
    • increases insulin sensitivity, protecting against the metabolic syndrome
    • anti-inflammatory effect
    • antiatherogenic effect
    • antiproliferative effect
    • cardioprotective effects
  • Its serum levels are lower in obese than in lean individuals.
  • These effects contribute to OBESITY ASSOCIATED INSULIN RESISTANCE, TYPE 2 DIABETES, AND NONALCOHOLIC FATTY LIVER DISEASE.

Key Takeaways:

  • Adiponectin's Role: Adiponectin stimulates fatty acid oxidation, reduces glucose production in the liver, and increases insulin sensitivity, protecting against metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes.
  • Protective Effects: It has anti-inflammatory, antiatherogenic, antiproliferative, and cardioprotective effects, earning it the nickname "guardian angel against obesity."
  • Levels in Obesity: Adiponectin levels are lower in obese individuals, contributing to obesity-associated insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
  • Why Others are Incorrect: Leptin and gut hormones are primarily involved in regulating appetite and energy expenditure, not directly addressing insulin resistance or type 2 diabetes.
